br.fml.eti.machinegun
Class MachineGun<T>

java.lang.Object
  br.fml.eti.machinegun.MachineGun<T>

public abstract class MachineGun<T>
extends java.lang.Object

A "machine gun" avoid stopping the main flow when expensive things is needed, like I/O operations. First, a MachineGun will put everything in an (limited) internal buffer, after some consumers will put it in an internal persisted queue to finally, others consumers to do the expensive operation. A "machine gun" is very useful, e.g., when you need a fast (and asynchronous) persistence into a (slow) database.

Everything can be externally monitored through a ArmyAudit.

abstract  void fire(T bullet, java.lang.String missionName)
           You can use a MachineGun to "fire" the data as fast as possible into an internal buffer to, after, be placed in an persisted embedded queue to be processed as soon as possible until finally reach the final target.

Method Detail

fire

public abstract void fire(T bullet,
                          java.lang.String missionName)
                   throws UnregisteredMissionException,
                          java.lang.InterruptedException

You can use a MachineGun to "fire" the data as fast as possible into an internal buffer to, after, be placed in an persisted embedded queue to be processed as soon as possible until finally reach the final target.

Parameters:
bullet - The data to be processed.
missionName - Where and how the "bullet" (data) will reach the target. You have to register a mission in the Army: see the Army.startNewMission(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, br.fml.eti.behavior.Factory>, br.fml.eti.machinegun.Capsule, int, int, int) to know how to do this.
Throws:
UnregisteredMissionException - If you forget to start a mission before using Army.startNewMission(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, br.fml.eti.behavior.Factory>, br.fml.eti.machinegun.Capsule, int, int, int).
java.lang.InterruptedException - If the army is busy (the internal buffer is full) so this function can block for a while.
